channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Donald Trump Jr. Drums Up Business in India, Some Ask What’s Being Sold
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. in front of Trump Towers after the project’s inauguration in Pune, India, on Wednesday.
item.description: The president’s son is in India on behalf of the family business, but word that he planned a speech on foreign policy took the controversy to a new level.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB, KAI SCHULTZ and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: New French Plan Aims to Keep Migrants, and Far Right, at Bay
item.media:description: A migrant camp along Canal Saint-Martin in Paris.
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron wants to make it faster and easier to expel migrants who are rejected for asylum. But critics say his new law would go too far.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: With Dozens of Schoolgirls Missing in Nigeria, Angry Parents Demand Answers
item.media:description: The school in Dapchi, Nigeria, where dozens of schoolgirls disappeared on Monday after an attack by Boko Haram.
item.description: Parents heckled a governor and attacked his motorcade after learning their daughters were still unaccounted for after a Boko Haram attack on a school in northern Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and EMMANUEL AKINWOTU

item.title: Blocked by Russia, U.N. Fails to Pass Syria Cease-Fire Resolution
item.media:description: The besieged Damascus suburb of eastern Ghouta has become “hell on earth,” a British envoy said Thursday. A man carried a wounded boy from bombed-out buildings there on Wednesday.
item.description: The resolution was intended to allow food and medicine to reach a besieged Damascus suburb, where conditions were described as “hell on earth.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and NADA HOMSI

item.title: Haiti Suspends Oxfam Great Britain After Sex Scandal
item.media:description: Aviol Fleurant, Haiti’s minister of planning and external cooperation, left, meeting on Thursday with the Oxfam officials Simon Ticehurst and Margalida Massot.
item.description: Two weeks after learning that Oxfam staff members had sex parties with prostitutes after the 2010 earthquake, the Haitian government is investigating.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: An Embassy, 850 Pounds of Cocaine and Now 6 Arrests
item.media:description: The authorities in Moscow making arrests on Thursday during a cocaine smuggling investigation.
item.description: The 14-month investigation was triggered by the discovery of $60 million of cocaine at the Russian Embassy in Argentina.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES NEWBERY

item.title: Elephant Tramples a Refugee Camp, and a Child is Killed
item.media:description: A sign saying “Warning! Route for Wild Elephants” near the Kutupalong-Balukhali refugee camp in Bangladesh.
item.description: Dozens of people were also injured after an elephant tore through the camp in Bangladesh, home to hundreds of thousands of Rohingya.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Mithi Journal: Pair of Killings Tests Hindu-Muslim Unity in a Pakistani Desert Town
item.media:description: Family members of the Kumar brothers, including Kekai Bai, their mother, at center.
item.media:credit: Danial Shah for The New York Times
item.description: In the remote town of Mithi, tolerance has been a byword for generations. But a recent influx of Muslim extremist parties is setting everything on edge.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK

item.title: Fearing Corruption Probe, Former Mexico Party Chief Moves to Block Arrest
item.media:description: Manlio Fabio Beltrones in Mexico City in 2016.
item.media:credit: Cristopher Rogel Blanquet/El Universal, via Associated Press
item.description: Manlio Fabio Beltrones has been implicated in a far-reaching graft investigation, according to documents and testimony reviewed by The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Ivanka Trump Arrives in South Korea for Games and Diplomacy
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump will meet with South Korea’s president and attend the Olympic closing ceremony, but officials played down speculation that she might meet with a North Korean delegation to the Winter Games.
item.description: The president’s daughter will meet with South Korea’s leader and attend the Olympic closing ceremony, where a North Korean delegation will also be present.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Gun Violence Draws Scorn in China as a Human Rights Issue
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. An opinion column in China’s Global Times newspaper said the United States should look to China, which has strict controls of guns.
item.description: The Communist Party-controlled Global Times said it was wrong for the U.S. to criticize another country’s human rights when it couldn’t control guns at home.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School (Parkland, Fla)

item.title: Books News: So, You Say You Want to Do the Splits?
item.media:description: The next Marie Kondo? Eiko, whose book “Even the Stiffest People Can Do the Splits” became a sensation in Japan.
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.description: Thank you for your service, Marie Kondo. Meet Eiko. In her new book, a mega-seller in Japan, this yoga teacher says even the stiffest people can do the splits.
item.dc:creator: HENRY ALFORD
item.category: Even the Stiffest People Can Do the Splits: A Four-Week Stretching Plan to Achieve Amazing Health (Book)

item.title: Iran Finally Let Her See Her Husband. He Was Dead.
item.media:description: Kavous Seyed Emami, an Iranian-Canadian environmentalist, who died in a Tehran prison this month, in what officials say was a suicide.
item.description: The authorities say Kavous Seyed Emami, a prominent environmentalist, committed suicide in prison. His wife and sons doubt that, and are demanding answers.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Barnaby Joyce, Australia’s Deputy Prime Minister, to Resign After Sex Scandal
item.media:description: Barnaby Joyce, a populist from rural Australia and a critical member of Parliament’s governing coalition, had admitted to an affair with a former staffer, who is currently pregnant.
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: Mr. Joyce, who admitted having impregnated a former staffer, was also accused of sexual harassment and of accepting gifts from supporters.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Beijing Takes Over Anbang, Insurer That Owns Waldorf Astoria
item.media:description: The Waldorf Astoria hotel, a symbol of New York elegance, will be under the control of the Chinese government.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: The troubled Chinese company had spent billions of dollars buying up hotels and other high-profile properties around the world.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Unicef Official Resigns Over His Past Conduct Toward Women
item.media:description: Justin Forsyth in 2016. He resigned on Thursday as a deputy executive director of Unicef.
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Justin Forsyth was accused of inappropriate behavior toward women when he was chief executive of the charity Save the Children.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: N.R.A., Manafort, Syria: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Syrian Militias Enter Afrin, Dealing a Setback to Turkey
item.media:description: People waving Syria’s flag and portraits of its president, Bashar al-Assad, and the leader of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, Abdullah Ocalan, as a convoy of pro-Syrian government fighters arrives in Syria’s northern enclave of Afrin on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Ahmad Shafie Bilal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Pro-government militias entered the northwest enclave in support of Kurdish fighters to broad welcome from residents, but not from Turkey.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: ‘A President I Can Be Proud of’: South Africans Express Their Hopes
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, center, during a morning walk in Cape Town, South Africa, on Tuesday.
item.description: As Cyril Ramaphosa takes office, readers outlined their expectations and concerns for life under their new leader.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Kremlin Opponent Aleksei Navalny Is Briefly Detained for Organizing Protests
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, center, at a rally in Moscow in January.
item.description: The complaint against the Russian opposition leader carries a 30-day sentence, which would conveniently sideline him for the presidential election on March 18.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Heads Up: In Post-Carnival Trinidad, the Party Never Really Ends
item.media:description: Raquel Vasquez La Roche, an artist and teacher, works on the framework for a costume for a moko jumbie band at Granderson Lab in Belmont, a Port of Spain suburb.
item.media:credit: Mark Lyndersay for The New York Times
item.description: Port of Spain is known for its exuberant annual Mardi Gras, but even when the Trinidadian capital is not filled with costumed revelers, it remains home to a vibrant arts scene.
item.dc:creator: ERIN MACLEOD

item.title: Greece Approves Bribery Investigation Involving Political Elite
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece told Parliament that his government would not cover up “one of the biggest scandals in the country’s modern history.”
item.description: A report sent to Parliament said there was evidence to suggest that Novartis made payments to politicians.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: As China Puts Pressure on Taiwan, Signs of a U.S. Pushback
item.media:description: Taiwanese sailors saluting their flag after military drills in January. President Trump signed legislation in September with a provision that encourages mutual port calls by ships from Taiwan and the United States.
item.description: Concern about the self-governing island’s fate seems to be building in Washington, even as President Trump seeks China’s help on other issues.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Former Spymaster to Lead North Korea’s Olympic Ceremony Delegation
item.media:description: Kim Yong-chol, who will lead North Korea’s delegation to the Olympic Games closing ceremony, at Panmunjom truce village in 2007.
item.media:credit: Lee Jin Man/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Kim Yong-chol, a high-ranking North Korean official accused of overseeing deadly attacks on the South, will visit South Korea to discuss the possibility of future talks.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Letter 46: Turnbull Goes to Washington, We Go to the Pub
item.media:description: Hobart’s New Sydney Hotel.
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.description: This week’s Australia Letter: Hobart’s best chicken Parma, and other news.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Bomb Thrown at U.S. Embassy in Montenegro; Attacker Kills Himself
item.media:description: The police guarded the entrance to the United States Embassy in Podgorica, Montenegro, early Thursday. An explosive device had been thrown onto the grounds.
item.description: Police say they have not found a motive for the attack, which did not injure anyone at the embassy, and did only minor damage.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK

item.title: When No Place Is Safe: Sheltering Under Siege in Syria
item.description: More than 200 people have been killed during an intense bombardment in eastern Ghouta, and underground shelters are filling up with fleeing residents.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Venezuela Opposition Will Boycott Election, and Maduro Tightens His Hold
item.media:description: Angel Oropeza of the opposition coalition, the Democratic Unity Roundtable, at a news conference on Wednesday. The group said the election offered only the “impression of legitimacy.”
item.description: The decision clears a path for President Nicolás Maduro’s re-election and threw the future of the nation’s political opposition further into doubt.
item.dc:creator: ANA VANESSA HERRERO and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Pakistan’s Top Court Rules Ousted Leader Can’t Head Political Party
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan in London last November. The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that he could not lead his political party.
item.media:credit: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Despite the ruling against the ex-prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, the real power of the country’s dominant political party still rests with him.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Gun Control, Billy Graham, Netanyahu: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Spanish Artwork Denounced Political ‘Persecution.’ It Was Ordered Removed.
item.media:description: “Contemporary Spanish Political Prisoners” by the Spanish artist Santiago Sierra. On Wednesday, it was ordered removed from an art fair in Madrid.
item.description: A gallery was ordered to withdraw a work that labeled Catalan separatist leaders as political prisoners from an exhibit at Madrid’s main arts fair.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Boko Haram Storms Girls’ School in Nigeria, Renewing Fears
item.description: Dozens of girls are missing after the militants raided a school, raising fears they may have been taken hostage just like girls from Chibok in 2014.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and EMMANUEL AKINWOTU

item.title: U.K.’s Governing Party Is Clashing Over ‘Brexit.’ Again.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain has often refused to reveal her objectives for leaving the European Union as she balance the demands of competing factions within her party.
item.description: Hard-line supporters of withdrawal are dismayed by a suggestion that the transition after leaving the European Union could be longer than two years.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Outrage as 2nd Bus Plunges Off Cliff in Peru, Killing Dozens
item.media:description: The scene of a deadly bus crash on Wednesday off the Pan-American Highway in Peru.
item.description: A passenger bus fell off a cliff on the nation’s most important highway, the second such deadly bus accident this year on the notoriously dangerous road.
item.dc:creator: MARCELO ROCHABRÚN

item.title: Max Desfor, 104, War Photographer at Midcentury, Is Dead
item.media:description: Max Desfor on his 99th birthday in 2012 in Rockville, Md.
item.description: Mr. Desfor’s photo of hundreds of Korean War refugees crawling across a damaged bridge in 1950 helped win him a Pulitzer Prize.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Carpetbagger: Mother Russia Crashes the Oscars
item.media:description: “They just keep attacking you, accusing you,” Feras Fayyad said of the Russian campaign against his film, “Last Men in Aleppo.”
item.media:credit: Joel Barhamand for The New York Times
item.description: The Oscar-nominated filmmakers behind “Last Men in Aleppo” and “Icarus” are grappling with a very real vexation: fear of Russian meddling.
item.dc:creator: CARA BUCKLEY

item.title: A Bombing in Northern Myanmar Signals Strife Beyond the Rohingya
item.media:description: A bomb exploded at a Yoma Bank branch in Lashio, a nearly lawless city in the northern part of Myanmar’s Shan State, on Wednesday. No one claimed responsibility, but the frontier region is plagued by ethnic violence.
item.description: While global attention has focused on the plight of Rohingya refugees, other long-running ethnic conflicts plague Myanmar’s restive borderlands.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and SAW NANG

item.title: Ireland Tells State-Run Schools: Stop Steering Pupils to Religion Class
item.media:description: Mercy Elementary School, a church-run school in Tuam, Ireland. The country is directing state-run secondary schools to offer alternatives for students who opt out of religion classes.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: The government told state-run secondary schools, though not the many church-run schools, to offer alternative courses.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Macau Journal: A Greyhound Racetrack Meets Its Demise
item.media:description: Dog handlers escorting greyhounds at the Macau (Yat Yuen) Canidrome last month. The track’s pending closing is a sign of changing times in the territory.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Animal-rights advocates have long criticized the track. Its closing also reflects the island’s transformation into a popular tourist destination for families.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Top Aide to Netanyahu Turns State Witness as Graft Cases Multiply
item.media:description: Shlomo Filber, left, in court in Tel Aviv on Sunday. He is a consummate political insider who has worked for the Likud Party since the mid-1990s.
item.description: The aide, Shlomo Filber, could support the most damning charge of favors to an Israeli communications giant in exchange for fawning news coverage.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Bahrain Activist Gets 5-Year Sentence for ‘Insulting’ Tweets
item.media:description: Nabeel Rajab, right, in 2014. Over the past few years, he has been in and out of jail on a series of charges related to his criticism of the monarchy in Bahrain.
item.description: Nabeel Rajab, a leading figure of pro-democracy rallies in 2011, had criticized prison abuses and the Yemen war. He was already serving time for criticizing the government.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: When Jokes Become a Crime: Free Speech Under Fire in Lebanon
item.media:description: The Lebanese comedian Hicham Haddad faces charges over jokes made on his popular television show.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: A surge of legal cases against entertainers, journalists and activists has raised concerns about one of the Arab world’s freest environments.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Reset, of Sorts, for the United States and Australia
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia in New York in May. The leaders’ relationship got off to a rocky start, but they have compelling reasons to work together.
item.description: President Trump and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, whose relationship got off to a rough start a year ago, will meet at the White House with much to discuss.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Australia Diary: ‘I Believe in Magic’
item.media:description: Me and a friend... and our mermaid pool.
item.description: What a teenager discovers in the enchanted rock pools near her home.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: Poland’s Nationalism Threatens Europe’s Values, and Cohesion
item.media:description: A view of Sniadowo, Poland. The district, a collection of villages northeast of Warsaw, overwhelmingly supports the Law and Justice party.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: The European Union has bestowed huge sums on Poland, but the country has fomented discord over identity, solidarity and, perhaps most important, the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and MARC SANTORA

item.title: Castellina in Chianti Journal: An Ancient Tuscan Village, Like Italy, Is Reshaped by Migration
item.media:description: Children at play in Castellina in Chianti, Italy. Immigration has quietly reshaped the village of 2,800: 17 percent of the population arrived from elsewhere.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Electoral campaign slogans warn against the migrants’ “invasion,” but Italy’s social fabric has already changed.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: North Korea Dropped Out of Meeting With Pence at Last Minute, U.S. Says
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence and Kim Yo-jong, the sister of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, stood near each other at the opening ceremony of the Winter Games this month in Pyeongchang, South Korea.
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence had planned to secretly meet with North Korean officials at the Winter Olympics in South Korea, the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and CHOE SANG-HUN
